title: Part 6
content:
Part 6

IN THE WHITE Room, there were dedicated rooms for various curriculums.

One of them was a heated pool, where you could swim all year round.

Swimming was considered to play a significant role in our physical training.

For still-immature bodies, like those of children, swimming was ideal due to its low impact. Moreover, the time spent interacting with water was precious for children's stress relief.

In the two-hour swimming sessions, there was a thirty-minute lesson at the beginning, followed by a ten-minute break.

Then, there was a thirty-minute period of competitive swimming with set goals and times.

After that, the children were given thirty minutes of free time.

We could leisurely swim in the water or choose to rest without swimming.

I had made it a habit to spend the remaining thirty minutes observing the children from the poolside.

"This is the place, huh? You set a new record today too."

"I still haven't reached the instructor's time."

"We're children, and the opponent is an adult. It's not strange that we can't win. What's frustrating is that I can't beat you anymore, Kiyotaka."

Until a few weeks ago, Yuki was the fastest regardless of swimming style.

"Ever since you overtook me, the gap in our records has been widening. How can you swim so well? I practice just as much…"

"Breathing."

"Huh?"

"Your form is perfect while swimming, but it breaks during breathing. If you improve that, you can shave off more time."

"I see… The instructor didn't point that out."

"The instructor in charge of swimming doesn't tell you everything. I think they want us to find out on our own."

It wasn't that I didn't notice.

"It's not just about yourself; you see your surroundings too. I don't have that kind of leeway."

"I'm also struggling to keep up."

Especially with curriculums I was trying for the first time, I often found myself lagging behind.

Without basic skills, my focus inevitably went to learning, and I couldn't produce good results.

On the other hand, people like Yuki and Shiro often performed well from their very first attempts.

They quickly absorbed the basics despite not knowing anything.

Perhaps that was what you would call having a "sense" of things. That was the difference.

However, I didn't envy it.

Even if there was a gap at the beginning, I could close it by learning and solidifying the basics, as proven by our numerous curriculums.

It was okay to be bad at first. Building a foundation and becoming capable of applying it myself was the priority.

Yuki didn't leave, opting to keep looking at me.

"…Do you need something else?"

"Is it weird to talk if I don't need anything?"

"Weird. Normally, people talk because they have something to discuss."

"You're the same as always, huh?"

Without looking at her, I started thinking about Yuki.

Lately, she had been talking more and more.

She spoke differently from me.

The frequency of her initiating conversations without any specific purpose had also increased.

Why would she do such inefficient things?

As an observational subject, she wasn't bad.

Moreover, there were no instructors nearby to overhear and reprimand us.

Of course, I couldn't deny that we were under surveillance, but there was nothing they could blame us for.

"Can I ask you something?"

"Eh? That's fine…"

Yuki was surprised by such a response and felt a bit bewildered.

"Why are you good at conversation, Yuki?"

"Eh? Am I good at it?"

"You're at least better than me. I just can't feel motivated to talk."

"I don't particularly have the motivation either, but… I don't know… I can't explain it."

Speaking without understanding yourself? Truly incomprehensible.

"Then, why can you laugh? You laughed before, right?"

"Why…? I don't know that either."

"You don't know? You changed, yet you don't know?"

"Because I can't laugh now."

Indeed, Yuki had laughed before, but since then, I couldn't recall seeing her laugh.

Was it just a chance that she laughed once?

Perhaps emotions were established through such coincidences.

"I don't know, but I feel like I can laugh again if I'm near you, Kiyotaka."

"I can't understand that."

Is it possible that people can't feel the emotion of laughter unless they're near someone specific?

No, there might've been some truth to that.

The instructors often showed anger, and most of it was directed at someone else.

Smiles were also shown to others.

Thinking this way, it wasn't completely incomprehensible.

I looked at Yuki.

"…What?"

I thought about smiling.

But I didn't know how to smile.

I hadn't learned the basics of emotions.

Without the basics, nothing could be done.

"It's nothing."

The fact that I haven't been taught probably means that emotions are unnecessary.

I stopped thinking about this matter.

Chapter 6: Hopelessness and a Way of Life
